A quick bit of gas tax holiday math.  The US gas tax is $0.18/gallon.  The average American drives ~13,000 miles per year.  At 25 - 30 mpg that's 500 gallons of gas per year.  The gas tax - which pays for our highways - costs us $100/car/year.

/12 Qualified immunity is not a law passed by Congress and signed by a president. It's a doctrine created by the Supreme Court. And it shields government officials from accountability when they violate Americans‚Äô civil rights. The Court MUST re-examine its misguided doctrine.

/11 We've gone from a law allowing any gov official to be sued by someone whom they deprived of their constitutional rights under color of state law to a system where gov officials acting in good faith were shielded from being sued to protecting gov officials acting in bad faith.

/10 What is considered a "clearly established" right? In practice, this means a police officer, or other government/state official acting under color of state law, can intentionally violate someone's rights and still be protected by qualified immunity.
/9 Instead, the Court ruled police officers and government officials have qualified immunity as long as they don't violate "clearly established law" that the officer would have been aware of.

/8 After this decision, known as Pierson v. Ray, the Court then rapidly expanded the doctrine of qualified immunity. And in 1982, the Court offered a reinterpretation because the "good faith" standard was too subjective.

/7 The priests used Section 1983 to sue the police. In 1967, their case made it to the Supreme Court, where it ruled that police officers have "qualified immunity" from those lawsuits because they were acting in "good faith" to enforce the law as they understood it at the time.

/6 After entering a "whites only" area of a bus terminal, the group was arrested and jailed for breach of peace. They received the maximum sentence of four months in jail plus a $200 fine, but the charges were dismissed on appeal.

/5 In 1961, a group of Black and white priests participated in the Freedom Rides, where civil rights activists rode buses in segregated Mississippi to challenge the non-enforcement of the recent Supreme Court ruling that found segregated public buses were unconstitutional.

/4 Then in the 20th century, as the Civil Rights Movement gained traction, Section 1983 would be reinterpreted by unelected judges, who transformed the statute through the application of qualified immunity.

/3 In response to this reign of terror, Congress created the Civil Rights Act of 1871, also known as the Ku Klux Klan Act, which allows those whose rights have been violated by state and local officials to sue for damages. This was later codified under 42 U.S.C Section 1983.

/2 During this time, the Ku Klux Klan formed, and its members sought to restore white supremacy by attacking newly freed Black Americans. Often, many government officials tasked with upholding the law were also part of the Klan.

QUALIFIED IMMUNITY

After the Civil War, the country ratified the 14th Amendment, which prohibited states from depriving any person of the equal protection of the laws. But the law was not being enforced for Black Americans.

How did this lead to qualified immunity?

State and local government officials who infringe on the constitutional rights of their citizens must be held accountable, but the doctrine of qualified immunity currently stands in the way. It is imperative, therefore, that we address this issue.

https://nadler.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=394824

Notably, the text of Section 1983 says nothing about qualified immunity, nor is it written in the Constitution. Qualified immunity subverts the very purpose of Section 1983 and denies justice to victims of state-sponsored abuse.

Unfortunately, the accountability that Congress sought to achieve remains largely unrealized. This is, in large part, because of court decisions applying and expanding legal protections for defendants through the doctrine of qualified immunity.

Section 1983 originated from the unwillingness of state officials to protect and enforce the constitutional rights of African Americans after the Civil War. During this period, the Ku Klux Klan and its allies used racial violence and terror to undo the gains of Reconstruction.

In 1871, Congress passed one of the earliest civil rights laws in our Nation‚Äôs history‚Äîthe Ku Klux Klan Act of 1871. Section 1 of that law, now codified as 42 U.S.C. ¬ß 1983, empowers individuals to sue state and local government officials who violate their federal rights.

It‚Äôs hard to fathom, but like so much in this war, we must hope for the best but prepare for the worst. 10/10

Putin has shown little regard for how he is viewed outside his circle of supporters. NATO should be having conversations about our potential responses now, *before* any such egregious action, so we can make clear to him & amongst ourselves what our options would be. 9/10

Finally, we must be clear-eyed about the use of chemical or nuclear weapons in this conflict. We pray that Russia won‚Äôt use them, and as I understand it, we haven‚Äôt seen signs they are preparing any such attacks ‚Äî but we must be prepared. 8/10
That should certainly mean exploring more forward presence by the U.S. military, and a more assertive approach overall. 7/10

We‚Äôve already seen shifts in defense policy among many of our European allies, but now is also the time - as the President negotiates his next budget - for us to rebuild the deterrence and security architecture in Europe. 6/10
Second, as the conflict in Ukraine continues, the U.S. & NATO need to think now about our long-term defense posture in light of what Putin has done. 5/10
For the U.S. & our allies, this means getting the Ukrainian military the weapons it needs, expediting delivery & further tightening the economic screws on Putin & the Kremlin. 4/10

A few takeaways: First, the war in Ukraine isn't about Ukraine alone. Russia thinks that it can wait the West out & simply create new facts on the ground. We need the result of this invasion to be Russia's defeat or else it only encourages more bad behavior by them & others. 3/10
